title: Can an employee refuse to help or train another employee? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a multi-layered question!! On first glance, the answer is no, not really. An employee will have to do as asked - i.e. help or train another employee. That is in the contract - ‘other duties’ statement. It applies to normal circumstances. However, I have also witnessed a situation where an employee was nominated to the main source to train, support and help a long-standing colleague returning from long-term sickness. No discussion about this nomination had taken place. The employee refused point blank to support his colleague when told of the decision. This refusal ruffled a lot of feathers and HR immediately resorted to policy, supported by the team manager, and penned a letter warning the employee of his behaviour and how it has undermined the manager of the team. The letter informed the employee that any further behaviour like this will result in disciplinary action. The employee responded citing the reasons why he was refusing to be the ‘main source’ of the returning colleague’s training etc. These reasons referred to: A long history of bullying and harassment at the hands of this colleague and the managerThe colleague’s performance history and disruptive attitude on project teams etcThe support he had to seek in the past to cope with the bullyingThat he was petrified of the vulnerable position this decision was putting him in and that he felt completely exposedHR had to withdraw their letter. It had been an ill-advised and poorly considered knee-jerk reaction. This is an extreme example of why the answer to the question is just as simple as saying ‘the employee will be fired’. It doesn’t, and shouldn’t, always work that way. There is often more to such a refusal than an employee simply refusing. It is worth forgetting the ‘lets refer to the policy’ approach for a little while and scratching beneath the surface. Implementing the policy should be your last resort because all it does is apply a ‘policing/enforcement’ approach to the situation. There are many reasons a person may not want to train/help his/her colleague. Your aim should be to identify the reasons/causes of this behaviour and do something about them rather than simply reaching for the reprimand. In a time when employee engagement, health and well-being such reprimands need to be preceded by a little fact-finding. If the colleague refusing to train/help their colleague is at fault, then the reprimand is justified. But it is always advisable to make sure you have carried out your research before reprimanding anyone. If members of a team are not prepared to help their colleagues, then there is a deeper malaise that no policy or procedure is going to fix. I think HR should be asking different questions. Of course, most situations will be ‘in normal circumstances’ and the employee should, of course, train and/or help their colleague.

Yes. An employee can refuse to help or train another employee. An employee can tag another employee as unfit tp be trained or quote any problems with the other employee to avoid training him. The employre can also quote his work pressure as an excuse for his inability to train or help another. Typically, to stay diplomatic and to look good in his boss's eyes, the employee may still take up the task but not really impart any training to the other employee. The latter is usually true. Therefore, trying to run after an employee who may have been straightforward is practically useless unless ypu may have any scores to settle with that employee.

Every job and job description contains or implies it contains the phrase ‘and other duties as assigned.’ That means the top VP can be asked to pick up the CEOs laundry. A CEO would be foolish to demand that, but he or she could… and anyone ranking above you in line of command can ask you to train others or whatever. Your choice is to quit, refuse and risk being fired or comply. And, for everyone’s sake, if you choose to comply, don’t subtly take it out on the person you’re assigned to help… or someone is likely to track you down and fire you for that.

You could refuse, but it might backfire on you. I guess it would depend on your job description and your ability to train another person, that might prevent you doing the leading, e.g. if you are illiterate and learnt the task verbally and by being shown. Mind you most illiterates seem to have a way of getting the other person to do the reading etc. I have been told in one instance that I was not a particular person’s supervisor… I said ok… and after that I didn’t train them in anything, I cited this reference a few times to make my point.

Yes they can, and they can be fired for it. I’ve fired an employee for exactly that reason. In my case, I had a team of engineers. Within the team, I had two Muslims. One was a man and the other was a woman. The woman was more senior. The man would not take direction from the woman and insisted that she ask someone else to do those tasks. He readily took direction from other men. I fired him.

This is one of the best questions I have seen here. Suppose training others is not in your contract, although you are obliged to do whatever your employer says under the contract and effective regulations, I think the employer should not be able to ask you to convey your professional knowledge to third parties without your will. But I am not sure on how it can be legally enforced at the moment.
“Can an employee refuse to help or train another employee?” Of course an employee can refuse to help of train another employee. However he or she should not be surprised when fired for cause.
I have seen companies tell a worker s/he is being fired but then expect the worker to training his/her replacement. I personally would refuse.
